Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Cyber-HealthGIS - Multidisciplinary Research Experiences in Spatial Dynamics of Health

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is funded from the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program in the SBE Directorate. As such, it has both scientific and societal benefits, and it integrates research and education. This REU Site combines the fields of Computing, Geographic Information Science (GIS), and Health on the Texas A&M University (TAMU) campus in College Station, TX where undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds in Computing, GIS, and Health work together on collaborative research projects in a newly emerging field called Cyber-Enabled HealthGIS (Cyber-HealthGIS). Thirty REU students (ten each year) are engaged in research teams to promote discovery, teaching, and training through hands-on research and mentoring. Students are mentored and trained in the basics of research techniques, the responsible conduct of research, the need for diversity in research, and research designs and methods. The REU Site students collaboratively pose, execute, and evaluate research projects resulting in research advances in Cyber-HealthGIS. Through this approach, students learn research and problem-solving outside of their own discipline, and gain independence and confidence in their own ability to undertake research. This program will advance the new field of Cyber-HealthGIS by building theory, methods, and approaches which will lead to joint faculty-student publications in research journals, seminars, and conferences, and student presentations of their own research. This program fills a critical US workforce gap by creating a generation of students trained for and interested in research and scientific careers in Cyber-HealthGIS, a rapidly advancing field with the potential to improve human health and well-being. The student projects and example prototypes developed through this program will be made freely available to help foster innovation and development in the Cyber-HealthGIS industry.

In this REU Site, the ideas from each student's academic/disciplinary domain is integrated to form a cohesive, achievable research goal under the umbrella of the core research themes of this project, which include (1) Outbreak surveillance through the combination of authoritative and social media data; (2) High-resolution chronic disease risk mapping with citizen-derived perceptions of community; and (3) Continuous time-enabled scalable outbreak planning. Students work closely with faculty mentors to pose the research question, develop testable hypotheses, obtain the necessary data, organize appropriate methods, engineer an approach, perform experiments, and undertake an evaluation of the results. This project will make freely available examples of prototype applications, thereby advancing the capabilities of Cyber-HealthGIS research through the development and release of free and open source (FOSS) code for the systems and example data sets used in the student research and experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes Report

Summary

The CyberHealthGIS REU Site was a summer research program for undergraduates to conduct multidisciplinary research in spatial dynamics of health that is CyberHealthGIS. 35 students participated over the three-summer span of 2016-2018. The goals of this REU site were to teach undergraduate students how to do research in the new field of CyberHealthGIS and to produce new knowledge in the field, giving them experience and preparing them for potential future careers in research. Students conducted research projects that covered five main areas that addressed open research challenges in CyberHealthGIS:

  • Navigation assistance. Projects consisted of researching and developing navigation-driven computing interfaces that leveraged health and GIS information for enhancing navigational challenges of different populations. Such projects included interfaces developed for blind users, pedestrians, bicyclists, and swimmers (Figure 1).

  • Activity behaviors. Projects consisted of researching and developing activity-driven computing systems that leveraged health and GIS information for reacting to everyday actions. Such projects included systems for detecting smoker habits, firefighter communications, and aviator fatigue (Figure 2).

  • Environmental scenarios. Projects consisted of researching and discovering insights from GIS data of environmental phenomena that affect the lives of various populations. Such projects included observations on the impacts of natural disasters on domestic violence, hurricanes landfall on dialysis centers, and tornado outbreaks on mortality rates (Figure 3).

  • Health analyses. Projects consisted of researching and discovering insights from GIS data of health phenomena for improving the state of public health. Such projects included observations on EPA toxics release on asthma rates, extreme heat on emergency medical service calls, and density of dentist offices on diabetes prevalence (Figure 4).

  • Migrational trends. Projects consisted of researching and discovering insights from GIS data of migrational patterns from large-scale events. Such projects included data analysis of human migration flow patterns and assessment of mosquito breeding grounds from unmanned aerial vehicles (Figure 5).

A diverse group of 35 undergraduate students---including 22 women and 18 persons of color---over the three summer period participated in the REU site, where they created a research plan, followed through with the plan and evaluation, created and presented a poster on the completed results, and also wrote a research paper on the completed results. In total, the students presented their work 91 times, each at 1-4 poster presentations at one of the host site's local research symposiums. Additionally, there were one conference paper and four journal articles peer-reviewed and published, and four journal articles submitted for peer review.

The REU site provided ample opportunities for training and professional development to participating undergraduates and their corresponding graduate student mentors. Graduate and undergraduate students learned about CyberHealthGIS, honed their research skills, and gained experience in working with data analysis, experimental design, presenting their results, with some of their papers receiving awards. As of the time of this submission, 12 participants enrolled in graduate studies.

Key Research Outcomes

This REU site demonstrated that undergraduate students were able to receive at least two key benefits from their summer research participation: learning and applying the growing importance of CyberHealthGIS knowledge into solving open research challenges and acquiring valuable research training for pursuing a research project within their program duration into completion. This means that students are more motivated and better prepared to apply this acquired knowledge and skills into research and pursue graduate studies and careers as researchers and educators.

The first benefit is that students worked with senior research mentors to select novel CyberHealthGIS research challenges, and subsequently explored the domain, developed the approach, and evaluated their progress. As a result, investigating these problems led to new knowledge and insights on their selected challenges.

The second benefit is that students were exposed to new foundational understanding of CyberHealthGIS research. As a result, students became more qualified as researchers in not only CSIE but in also CyberHealthGIS, and may potentially be more motivated to pursue this career path and expand the nation's pool of researchers for addressing valuable open problems in the domain.

The third benefit is that the graduate research mentors of the REU site's participating undergraduate students worked closely in collaborating with them on their research project progress. As a result, the graduate student mentors received valuable research, technical, and management training experience from the program duration to become stronger leaders as researchers and educators following their graduate studies.

Overall, we believe that the CyberHealthGIS REU site fulfilled its goals of both teaching undergraduate students how to do research in the new field of CyberHealthGIS and also producing new knowledge in the field. Students who participated in the REU site received research training for properly preparing them to conduct and successfully complete a research project with collaborators, and at the minimal presented their research to a general audience at a public research symposium and with some also publishing their work at an international peer-reviewed research archive.
